results.title: Et cetera. Episode 6 [Joe Felber Multimedia Installation]
results.creator_credit: David McLauchlan, Michael Costello and Northern Access TV
results.brief_description: Presented by David McLauchlan outside the Australian Centre for Contemporary Art, Melbourne. David interviews multimedia artist Joe Felber and dancer/choreographer Lucy Guerin about their collaborative installation with composer Elliott Gyger entitled “25 songs on 25 lines of 25 words on Art Statement for seven voices and dance” based on Ad Reinhardt’s Black Painting and Art Statement. Following the interviews, there is a presentation of Joe Felber’s 7 minute video on the multimedia performance “25 songs on 25 lines…and dance”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David McLauchlan, Michael Costello and Northern Access TV

results.title: Et cetera. Episode 3 [1999 Melbourne Fringe Festival]
results.creator_credit: David McLauchlan, Michael Costello and Northern Access TV
results.brief_description:
Documents the 1999 Melbourne Fringe Festival Parade and the Fringe Furniture Exhibition, including interviews with Virginia Hyam, Fringe Director, and Axel, Fringe Furniture Co-ordinator. The Melbourne Fringe Festival has become an institution since its inception in 1982 when a small group of independent artists gathered together to create a platform to present new and independent art to the community. From those early beginnings the Melbourne-based festival now attracts interstate and international guests and covers a wide variety of arts
performances including outdoor events such as the Annual Parade in Brunswick Street, Fitzroy, the Annual Waiter’s Race, street-theatre and live bands and indoor events including comedy and cabaret, music and theatre. The Fringe Furniture Exhibition allows for young students
and designers an opportunity to show-off their creative ability and caters for non-mainstream pieces. Crazy, outrageous, quirky and even occasionally practical, the Exhibition contains an amazing selection of eclectic pieces as witnessed in this documentary program.
Reporters: Melissa Iaria and Phillip Taylor.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David McLauchlan, Michael Costello and Northern Access TV

results.title: Access News greatest hits 2000. Part 2
results.creator_credit: Campbell Manderson, Pip Starr and SKA TV
results.brief_description:
Access News Greatest Hits 2000 (Part 2 of 2)
SKA TV’s Access News is a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.
Giving light to perspectives or issues otherwise not seen, stories range from front-line coverage of anti-globalisation protests to satirical critiques of commercial media.
‘Greatest Hits 2000’ is a compilation of 15 of Access News’s best stories from the year 2000.
Highlights from part 2:
Fortress Goolengook : After having their camp destroyed by loggers, forest blockaders in the heart of East Gippsland’s Goolengook forest build an elaborate fortress (including drawbridge!) to ensure their safety against further attacks.
Viva Falantil : A tour through a newly-independent East Timor, still shell-shocked and facing an uncertain future. This story examines the possibilities for and obstacles to building a democratic nation.
Herald Sun Occupation : During the World Economic Forum (WEF) held in Melbourne in September 2000, a group of protesters went to the Herald Sun newspaper to voice their concern the paper’s exceptionally biased coverage of the protests outside the WEF.

results.title: Viva Falantil!
results.creator_credit: Campbell Manderson, Pip Starr and SKA TV
results.brief_description: Report on a group of performers and activists who stowed away on a UN flight bound for East Timor to raise awareness of the plight of the Falintil people and their 20 year struggle against the East Timorese military. A tour through a newly-independent East Timor, still shell-shocked and facing an uncertain future. This story examines the possibilities for and obstacles to building a democratic nation. Produced as a news story for SKA TV’s Access News, a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.

results.title: The Olympic flame and the peace fire
results.brief_description:
The year 2000 saw water in the normally dry Lake Eyre. Life flourished there. But nearby, uranium mining was poisoning the land, and sucking millions of litres of artesian water each day. If Sydney was the headquarters for the Olympic Games, the shores of Lake Eyre was the base for a group of peace activists.
In June of that year, two very different journeys commenced. One was the journey of the Olympic Torch and the other was a walk by group of people carrying a sacred fire with them, who wanted to spread the message of peace.
This documentary explores the beginnings of both journeys. It presents the start of the Olympic Torch relay through another perspective and shows what wasn’t seen by a global Olympic audience - a walk by a small group of people from the the shores of Lake Eyre to Sydney to raise awareness about nuclear issues and promote peace.
The decision to do some filming was made in Coober Pedy two days before the Olympic Torch Relay commenced. In an old Subaru station wagon, Melbourne-based Sam de Silva, Michael Lumsdon and ‘Fergus’ travelled to Uluru, Alice Springs and Lake Eyre Peace Camp over a period of 3 days to document the story of the Olympic Flame and the Peace Fire.
An Access News story. Voice over by Alex Kelly.

results.title: Emu Spew
results.creator_credit: Campbell Manderson, Pip Starr and SKA TV
results.brief_description: Report on the efforts of the Adnyamathanha people, traditional landowners of the Northern Flinders Rangers to stop the Beverly Uranium Mining Project. The report also covers police action against the protestors and the unsafe method the mining company are using to extract the uranium. Produced as a news story for SKA TV’s Access News, a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.
